While everyone around us is buzzing with excitement about their vaccination appointment, we become more and more resigned and resentful, especially since we pull the longest hours, have the fewest days off, and are expected to see COVID patients without being able to refuse.

It's shameful and a slap in the face after all the front-line work we're expected to do. People are starting to notice but no one is doing anything about it. Residents are too afraid and/or defeated to protest.

BMC did vaccinate a few ICU and ED residents early on, so at least they did that part right and are a bit better than Stanford. But the rest of residents were not prioritized for vaccines despite being forced to see COVID patients.
However, there are some departments where no residents have been contacted to schedule a vaccination, or it has been offered to 1-2 residents in the department (out of a resident cohort of >30).
Residents were supposedly in Wave 1 of the vaccine roll-out, which included approximately 3500 people in the first cohort, with 2500 emails being sent out to "front line staff" as of yesterday.
- Some attendings pulled strings to get themselves to the front of the vaccination line, while their residents had not yet been offered the vaccine

- For example, residents will spend up to an hour doing a procedure in the ED on a COVID rule out/positive patient while some attendings who have been vaccinated don't even know where the ED is located
- Each of those departments have residents who are exposed to COVID on a daily basis (ED, wards, etc) while their attendings avoid COVID rule-out/positive patients

- Chairmen of all departments have been vaccinated - In several departments, all of the attendings were vaccinated prior to any residents being offered the vaccine - Additionally, all the midlevels (NP/PA) have been vaccinated prior to the residents in those departments

- The first person vaccinated was the associate chief nursing officer, a non-clinical administrative role - Many other non-clinical administrators were vaccinated in the first couple of days of vaccine distribution, including staff educators, managers, etc.
